metadata.title: Are series getting worse over time? | by Amanda Iglesias Moreno | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Are series getting worse over time?
metadata.description: Have you ever had the feeling that your favorite series was losing quality over time? That you were not so hooked as before. Yes…I had this feeling. 😐 In this article, I analyze whether other…

all_paragraphs: Have you ever had the feeling that your favorite series was losing quality over time? That you were not so hooked as before. Yes…I had this feeling. 😐

In this article, I analyze whether other viewers have the same impression by examining the scores available IMDb. IMDb is an online database of information related to series, movies, and videos. All series contained in the database have an episode guide, where information about each episode (title, rate, release date, and plot) is available.

To perform this analysis, first, we are going to extract the rates of each episode with BeautifulSoup, and store them in a Pandas data frame. Then, we are going to visualize the results with heatmaps using Seaborn library.

If you are interested in the code used to extract the rates from IMDb web page as well as to generate the heatmaps, read until the end since first we provide the results and then we explain how we obtained them! So… Let’s get started ⭐️

On many occasions, I had the feeling that a series took longer than it should. Successful series have generally many seasons, running the risk of getting repetitive. Next, we analyze 5 series that present a gradually declining quality over time or a precipitous drop in the last season.

Prison Break is an American television series released in 2005. The series tells the story of Michael Scofield a brilliant structural engineer who elaborates a plan to help his brother Lincoln Burrows to escape from jail. Lincoln was incarcerated and sentenced to death after being accused of killing the brother of the Vice President of the United States.
The following heatmap shows the score of every episode. As you can observe, the first two seasons have on average higher scores than the rest.

The Walking Dead is an American series released on AMC in 2010. The series presents a post-apocalyptic world where a group of survivors tries to stay alive under the constant attacks of the zombies while facing conflicts with other human survivors. As we can observe, the scores gradually decrease over time.

Money Heist is a Spanish television series originally released on Antena 3 in 2017. After being bought by Netflix, Money Heist has become a worldwide phenomenon. The series tells the story of the Royal Mint heist organized by ‘El Profesor’. After planning the robbery for years, El Profesor recruits eight robbers code-named after cities (Tokyo, Nairobi, Rio, Berlin, Moscow, Denver, Olso, and Helsinki) to execute his master plan: print 2.4 billion euros and escape successfully from the Mint.
As shown above, the scores of many episodes of the last season have decreased substantially (around 1 point); however, they increase at the end of the season (episodes 7 and 8).
I have to admit that Money Heist is one of my favorite series ❤️

Game of Thrones is an American series aired on HBO in 2017, being an adaptation of a series of fantasy novels written by George R. R. Martin. The series presents the story of the conflicts and alliances among dynasties to gain the Iron Throne.
As you can observe below, the scores of the episodes are really high during all seasons, showing a substantial decrease in the last one.

Black Mirror is a British dystopian television series released in 2011. The series criticises the modern society, particularly the inappropriate use of technology. All episodes are independent and present a near future where technology plays an important but also harmful role.
As shown above, we can also observe a decrease in scores in the last season.

Series such as House of Cards, Vikings, Gossip Girl, and The Sinner also show a declining quality over time according to IMDb users. But, are there series that maintain their quality over time? The answer is yes!
Although many series lose quality over time, there are others that manage to maintain the quality throughout the seasons. Let’s see some examples.
Breaking bad is just perfect. A puzzle where all the pieces fit together beautifully. Nothing is missing, nothing is superfluous. Needless to say that Breaking bad is my favorite series! 💚

The series was released in 2008 on AMC, and tells the story of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher who after being diagnosed with inoperable lung cancer, starts to produce meth to guarantee his family’s financial future.
As shown below, the series even increases its quality over time.
I completely agree with the users of IMDb. The last chapter of the Season 4 is simply perfect.
Friends is an American series aired on NBC in 1994. The series tells the story of six friends (Rachel, Monica, Phoebe, Joey, Chandler, and Ross) who live in New York.
Due to the success of Friends and after multiple salary negotiations, the cast was paid 1 million dollars per episode in seasons nine and ten!
As shown above, we observe differences in scores between episodes; however, there is no apparent declining quality throughout the seasons.

How to Get Away with Murder is an American series released in 2017 on ABC. The series tells the story of Annalise Keating a law professor at Middleton university and a successful attorney. She and five of her students get involved in the murder of Annalise’s husband Sam Keating.

In this particular case, we cannot appreciate a decreasing quality over time. However, we can notice that the last chapters of the seasons are rated better than the first ones. We can observe this trend practically in all series!
Now, it is time to make your own visualizations!

First, we present the third-party libraries used in this article. Since these libraries are not part of the Python Standard Library, we need to install them separately. This can easily be achieved using the pip package. Verify that all libraries are installed before executing the code on your computer.
Then, we provide the code used to scrape the data from IMDb web page and to generate the heatmaps, so you can easily make your own visualizations!
Request is a third-party library that allows you to send HTTP requests using Python. In this article, we will only use the request library to get the HTML code of a web page.

When performing data analysis, we are not always able to download the data in csv format, or to access it via an Application Programming Interface (API). In some cases, we have to obtain the data directly from the web page. That is when Beautiful Soup comes in handy.

Beautiful Soup is a Python library for extracting data from HTML and XML documents, and has many useful functions to scrape information from web pages (e.g. to extract hyperlinks, text from tags, or images).

Pandas is a Python open-source library for data science that allows us to easily work with structured data, such as csv files, SQL tables, or Excel spreadsheets. It provides tools for reading and writing data in different formats, for carrying out exploratory analysis, and for data cleaning.

Seaborn is a Python data visualization library based on Matplotlib. In comparison to Matplotlib, Seaborn allows you to make plots using fewer lines of code and provides more sophisticated visualization tools such as heatmaps, box plots, and violin plots. In addition, the visualizations look much better! ❤️

To scrape the data from IMDb, we create a function (episodes_rates) that accepts as input the web page of a series ( Episode Guide), returning a data frame where the rows represent the seasons and the columns the episodes as follows:
Let’s understand the code step by step 👌

1. We use the request module to obtain the HTML code of the web page as a string. First, we send a GET request to the specified url using .get(url) method. Then, we get the HTML text of the page using the .text attribute.

As we can observe, the url consists of two parts: url_serie and url_season. Url_serie is the input of the function (episodes_rates) and remains unchanged while url_season (e.g. ?season=1, ?season=2, …) changes as we select different seasons.

2. We pass the string html into the BeautifulSoup constructor, obtaining a BeautifulSoup type object. Now, we can easily extract information from this object using the methods available in Beautiful Soup.

3. Next, we explore the HTML code with Chrome Dev Tools. Chrome Dev Tools is a set of web developer tools built directly into Google Chrome, allowing you to easily inspect the HTML code of a page. We can easily access Chrome Dev Tools by clicking Ctr + Shift + I or by selecting More Tools > Developer Tools.

In the elements tab, we can inspect and edit the HTML and CSS of a page. To display the HTML code for an element (e.g. episode rate), you can click the inspect element button (square with the arrow) and select the item in the browser as follows:

As we can observe, the element of interest (episode rate) is inside the span tag with a class attribute (“ipl-rating-star__rating”). This span tag is inside a division tag with a class attribute (“ipl-rating-star small”).

We use the method .find_all() to obtain all tags with the class attribute (“ipl-rating-star small”). This function returns a bs4.element.ResultSet object. Then, we loop through this object (division tags), accessing to the span tag that contains the score (“ipl-rating-star__rating”) using the .find() method. To obtain the text between the tags, we use the .text attribute as follows.
As shown above, we insert the scores in a dictionary, being the keys the episode number and the values the score of the episode. Finally, we append this dictionary to a list.

4. Once we have collected all scores of a season, we have to access the url of the next season to continue collecting scores. First, we check whether another season is available (anchor tag — id=”load_next_episodes”). If so, we access the url contained in the href attribute using the .get() method.
As shown above, if there is not anchor tag with id=”load_next_episodes”, meaning there is not another season available, the while loop is terminated.
5. Finally, we obtain a list of dictionaries, where each dictionary contains the scores of one season. We use this list of dictionaries to create a pandas data frame as follows:
And voilà! We obtain a data frame, providing only a web page 💪 Next, we use this data frame to create a heatmap using Seaborn.

A heatmap is a data visualization technique where the value of each data point is indicated using colors (variation of hue or intensity). We can easily create a heatmap with Seaborn using the seaborn.heatmap() function.

As shown below, we create a function webpage_to_heatmap that accepts as input the web page of the series ( Episode Guide), the colormap of the image as well as the title, returning a heatmap visualization. As you can observe, we use the data frame returned by the function episodes_rates as input to the seaborn.heatmap() function.
Now, Let’s pick a series and visualize its scores!
First, we go to the episode guide of a series, and we copy the url until the word episode as follows:
Then, we pick a colormap and a title for the visualization. Finally, we create the heatmap with the webpage_to_heatmap function.
As you can see, Mad Men increases its quality over time! In addition, the last chapters of the seasons are rated better than the first ones.
Now, it is time to make your own visualizations!

Data Scientist at Statista — Based in Hamburg 📍
